dc:description:
*WRAP53* was first reported in relation to semidominant telomere syndrome in 2011 (Zhong et al., PMID: 21205863). Individuals with *WRAP53* variants presented with features of the classic dyskeratosis congenita triad (oral leukoplakia, nail dystrophy, abnormal skin pigmentation), bone marrow failure, short telomeres, and a variable age of onset, some with other features reported in addition to these findings (PMID: 21205863). Importantly, interstitial lung disease was not reported to be a feature found in any of the cases, but one case did have hepatopulmonary syndrome and respiratory insufficiency (PMID: 37149759). 

Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanisms or phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been lumped into one disease entity: Dyskeratosis congenita, autosomal recessive 3 (OMIM:613988), Hoyeraal-Hreidarsson syndrome, early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, myelodysplastic syndrome, and aplastic anemia. Other assertions have been made for Ewing sarcoma (PMID: 28125078), pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 31470354), primary immunodeficiency (PMID: 32888943), craniometadiaphyseal dysplasia (PMID: 34484289), gastric cancer (PMID: 28875981), and breast cancer (PMID: 17683073); however, these additional assertions were split for various reasons including sequencing errors (PMID:36116037), presence of variants in other genes, and high allele frequencies. 

Eleven missense variants that have been reported in 8 probands across 7 publications (PMIDs: 21205863, 29514627, 32303682, 34599657, 30552426, 37149759, 30523342) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity is reported to be a loss of function that results in shortened telomeres (PMID: 21205863). 

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence including biochemical function data that is consistent with the phenotype (PMID: 19179534), protein interactions with other genes known to cause dyskeratosis congenita (PMID: 32303682), functional alteration in iPSCs that demonstrate the human disease process (PMID: 21602826), and a cell culture model that displayed telomere shortening (PMID: 19179534).

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Interstitial Lung Disease GCEP on the meeting date June 17, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: Depletion of TCAB1 in cells over-expressing WT TERC significantly inhibited telomere elongation, mimicking the effect of the CAB box mutation. To determine whether TCAB1 is required for telomere synthesis by endogenous telomerase, the authors assayed telomere lengths with serial passage in HTC75 cells transduced with TCAB1 shRNAs or with empty vector. Both shRNAs targeting TCAB1 led to progressive telomere shortening, which is a feature observed in individuals with TBDs, compared to the empty vector control.
evidence.rdfs:label: TCAB1 Depletion Inhibits Telomere Elongation

evidence.dc:description: In WT iPSCs, TCAB1 colocalized in discrete foci with the Cajal body marker p80-coilin, whereas TCAB1-mutant iPSCs exhibited a dramatic reduction of TCAB1 accumulation in Cajal bodies. Dyskerin normally accumulates both in Cajal bodies, where it binds small Cajal Body RNAs (scaRNAs) and TERC, and in the nucleolus, where it binds H/ACA small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs). Efficient accumulation of dyskerin in Cajal bodies requires functional TCAB1. TCAB1-mutant iPSCs showed a significant reduction in dyskerin accumulation in Cajal bodies, whereas nucleolar localization of dyskerin was unperturbed. RNA FISH using probes complementary to TERC revealed that, whereas TERC localized to a single Cajal body focus in WT iPSCs, it dramatically mislocalized to nucleoli in TCAB1-mutant iPSCs. These data show that TCAB1 mutations in patient-derived iPSCs result in mislocalization of the telomerase complex.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mislocalization of Telomerase in TCAB1-mutant iPSCs

evidence.dc:description: This function has been demonstrated by several other papers (PMIDs: 22547674, 21205863) and is well-established. Telomerase plays an essential role in maintaining telomere length.

TERC is a component of the telomerase complex. Telomerase is an enzyme that maintains the telomere length, by adding DNA repeats, which prevents chromosome shortening. TERC localization was measured by RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) in TCAB1-depleted HeLa cells. TCAB1 knockdown significantly reduced the percentage of cells in which TERC was found in Cajal bodies. Cajal bodies have been directly implicated in the delivery of TERC to telomeres. Thus, TCAB1 controls telomerase trafficking and is required for telomere synthesis. In the absence of telomerase, progressive telomere shortening occurs. Short telomeres is a defining feature of telomere biology disorders
evidence.rdfs:label: TCAB1's role in telomerase trafficking

evidence.dc:description: Immunoprecipitation of GFP-WRAP53β followed by western blotting or RT-PCR confirmed that the wild-type protein co-precipitates with components of the telomerase complex (including DKC1, NHP2, NOP10, GAR1 and TERC) (Fig. 3a, b), as well as with various scaRNAs (including those with C/D boxes (i.e., scaRNA2) and H/ACA boxes (i.e., scaRNA5 and TERC)) (Fig. 3c). DKC1 and TERC have both been curated for dyskaratosis congenita and reached a definitive classification.
evidence.rdfs:label: WRAP53β interaction with components of telomerase and scaRNA

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Gly435Arg, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=2.800e-7 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.

In vitro functional expression studies in HeLa cells and patient cells showed that the mutant WRAP53 protein impaired normal telomerase trafficking, leading to a loss of telomerase complex components, including TCAB1, dyskerin, and TERC from Cajal bodies.
This missense variant, Tyr345Cys, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.00007408 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Papuc Patient 73450
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Early onset and therapy resistant absence seizures. DEE (combined developmental and epileptic encephalopathies). Crawling at 9m, sitting at 2y, walking at 2y 2m, 40 words at 2y 6m. Moderate ID at 2y 6m, DQ 75 at 12m. Cerebellar-medullary arachnoid cyst at age 2y 2m. HC (P<3), L (P<3), W (P<3). Premature birth at 32 GW (placental insufficiency), sleep disorder. Referred for GDD after normal initial development. Telomeres are short (<1st %ile)

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Arg298Trp, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.000002920 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes. Down-scored for consanguinity, homozygosity, and sequencing methods.

Colony assay of mononuclear cells from patient’s bone marrow were seeded into methylcellulose cultures. Compared with the normal control, the colony formation of BMMNCs from the proband (IV-1) was significantly lower.

evidence.rdfs:label: Shao Proband IV-1
evidence.detectionMethod: An NGS assay was designed to cover all exons, splice sites, and the flanking intron sequences of 9 DC-associated genes (DKC1, TERC, TERT, NHP2, NOP10, CTC1, RETL1, WRAP53, and TINF2). To confirm the WRAP53 Arg298Trp mutation identified by NGS, the corresponding WRAP53 gene region surrounding the mutation was amplified by PCR and sequenced by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pancytopenia (WBC = 2.73 × 109/L, Hb = 94 g/L and PLT = 12 × 109/L). Leukoplakia on his buccal mucous membrane, and skin with spotted pigmentation in the posterior chest and neck. Hb level of 48 g/L, an MCV of 91.7 fl, a WBC of 0.4 × 109/L, a PLT of 6 × 109/L, and a reticulocyte count of 0.0116 × 1012/L, liver function test showed normal functioning (ALT = 33.70 U/L, AST = 30.10 U/L, TBIL = 14.70 μmol/L). Telomere length in the peripheral blood lymphocytes corresponded to less than the 1st percentile of age-matched controls. Treatment with danazol, glucocorticoid and/or CsA during the 3 years following the initial presentation (although no definite diagnosis had been made then), but had no response; his symptoms became worse, and he became transfusion dependent over time.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Cytogenetic study showed a normal karyotype, there was no increase in the chromosomal breakage as measured by single cell gel electrophoresis (SCGE) and mitomycin C (MMC) tests. The tests for mutations of DKC1, TERC, TERT, NHP2, NOP10, CTC1, RETL1, and TINF2 were negative. Telomere length measurements of peripheral blood lymphocytes were performed by flow cytometry with fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis (flow-FISH)

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Val302Phe, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=8.474e-7 (1/1180030 alleles) in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.
This missense variant, Arg398Trp, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.00008341 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.

In vitro functional expression studies in HeLa cells and patient cells showed that the mutant WRAP53 protein impaired normal telomerase trafficking, leading to a loss of telomerase complex components, including TCAB1, dyskerin, and TERC from Cajal bodies.

evidence.rdfs:label: Friedrich Patient
evidence.detectionMethod: trio exome sequencing with Sanger sequencing validation
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Myelodysplastic syndrome, skin and congenital anomalies. Telomere length was 0.58.  Hepatopulmonary syndrome. Mouth corner fissures. From an early age, the patient had sickle feet, which were treated with orthoses. Telangiectasias on both cheeks.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No mutation in GATA2, RUNX1, SAMD9, SAMD9L

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Gly435Arg, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=2.800e-7 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes. The score has been reduced to 0 since PARN and RTEL1 were not sequenced

In vitro functional expression studies in HeLa cells and patient cells showed that the mutant WRAP53 protein impaired normal telomerase trafficking, leading to a loss of telomerase complex components, including TCAB1, dyskerin, and TERC from Cajal bodies.

This missense variant, His376Tyr, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=7.900e-7 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes. The score has been reduced to 0 since PARN and RTEL1 were not sequenced

In vitro functional expression studies in HeLa cells and patient cells showed that the mutant WRAP53 protein impaired normal telomerase trafficking, leading to a loss of telomerase complex components, including TCAB1, dyskerin, and TERC from Cajal bodies.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zhong Family 2 Patient NCI-202-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Bidirectional sequence analysis of all 10 exons of TCAB1. PCR and sequence analysis were independently repeated three times and reviewed by individuals blinded to patient status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Classic DC symptoms, including the diagnostic cutaneous triad and BMF. Telomere length less than the first percentile as compared with age-matched controls (Fig. 1B, Flow FISH of telomere lengths in peripheral blood lymphocytes).
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No mutations in any of the six known DC genes (DKC1, TERC, TERT, TINF2, NOP10, and NHP2).

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Gly379Ser, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.00003069 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.

This missense variant, Ser384Leu, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF that is n/a due to removal of low quality genotypes. In gnomAD v2.1.1, the highest allele frequency was 0.00002905 (1/34422 alleles) in the Admixed American population with 0 homozygotes

evidence.rdfs:label: Brailovski Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: A gene panel for bone marrow failure composed of 136 genes was performed
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: hemoglobin 64 g/L, mean corpuscular volume 106.7fL, reticulocytes 68 × 109/L, platelets 89 × 109/L, leucocytes 4.3 × 109/L, and neutrophils 2.9 × 109/L. reduced trilineage hematopoiesis. mild dyserythropoiesis consistent with aplastic anemia. serum sickness and posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome with seizures. transfusion of 1–2 units of packed red blood cells per month. Telomere lengths were below 1% as determined by flow-FISH.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No etiology was identified through viral serology testing, blood flow cytometry, and karyotyping. Chromosome breakage analysis was normal.

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Arg398Trp, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.00008341 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.
Transfection in HeLa cells showed that this variant leads to destabilization, mislocalization and impairment of WRAP53 function in Cajal bodies, at telomeres and in DNA repair.
This missense variant, Leu283Phe, is absent in gnomAD v4.1.0.
Transfection in HeLa cells showed that this variant leads to destabilization, mislocalization and impairment of WRAP53 function in Cajal bodies, at telomeres and in DNA repair.

evidence.rdfs:label: Bergstrand HHS Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: array CGH, WES, Sanger sequencing for confirmation
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGH) (reflected in the birth weight of 1242 g, length 39 cm, head circumference 27 cm (all −3.5 SD, apgar scores 10, 10, 10). Volvulus (50% of his small intestine was removed). Digestive tract anomalies and eating difficulties (i.e., oesophageal strictures, varices, and severe hemorrhages). Cortical malformation. Poor myelinization. Delayed psychomotor development (i.e. no speech). Erythropenia. Fibrosis (grade 3 out of 4) and malformation of the liver. Dilated intrahepatic choledochus. Elevated blood levels of transaminases. Retinal abnormalities and vitreous body hemorrhaging. Dysmorphic features of the face and body (i.e., dark gray eyes, cup-shaped ears, and fine blond hair). Telomere length <1st percentile.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Targeted sequencing of TERC, TINF2 (exon 6), and DKC1 (exon 3, 4, and 11) was performed

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Arg92Gly, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.000001830 in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gutierrez-Rodrigues Patient USP072
evidence.detectionMethod: For the USP cohort, patients were screened using a customized panel with 164 genes related to bone marrow failure syndromes, hematologic malignancies, and telomere maintenance whereas the patients from the NIH cohort were screened using the Inherited Bone Marrow Failure Sequencing panel performed by the University of Chicago Genetic Services Laboratory (Chicago, IL, USA). Massively parallel amplicon-based sequencing assay for detection of TERTp variants.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Aplastic anemia dx (AA patients presented with pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow), telomere length below the first percentile of age-matched controls (TL was measured by Southern blot (SB), quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), or flow fluorescent in situ hybridization (flow-FISH))
evidence.previousTestingDescription: All patients, relatives, and controls were previously screened for germline variants in telomere biology genes using the massively parallel targeting sequencing panel.
